AND DEVELOPMENT
Call for Knowledge, Ingenuity, Teamwork
Making new products in large amounts, devising new processes, and improving old ones—such problems are the job of
Design and Development. An example was the development
of a large-scale process for making "Orion" acrylic fiber
starting from small laboratory samples of polyacrylonitrile.
Quantity production of polymer was only a beginning. A
whole set of new and unusual problems arose in spinning the
fiber, because polyacrylonitrile decomposes before it melts,
and it dissolves only in high-boiling solvents.
A team of Du Pont technical men—chemical and mechanical engineers,instrumentation specialists, metallurgists, and
materials handling experts undertook to find a solution.
Here are a few of the problems they met:
1. Solve problems in heat transfer and fluid flow
arising from the fact that the spinning solution
must be blanketed with inert gas to prevent fire
hazards.
2. Design a system for controlling the temperature of the viscous spinning solution within ±0.5°F.
at hundreds of points in the plant.
3. Design new mechanisms for winding yarn at
high speed without any deviation in yarn tension.
4. Design air conditioning and ventilating systems to remove fumes from specific spots, but
still allow easy access to all areas.

Flash Equipment
A Specialty

The characteristics of a super-pressure pump,
designed by Du Pont engineers and made in
Du Pont shops,are studied by Ralph C.Grubb,
B.S.M.E., Tennessee '51, and Paul D. Kohl,
B.S.M.E., Purdue '46.

Among Du Pont's many research and engineering activities, Design and Development jobs provide great opportunity for the knowledge,- ingenuity, and teamwork capacities of men in a great variety of technical fields.

Carl Hellman, B.S.Ch.E., Syracuse '50, and

'60,search for new ways to coatplastic on wire.

The Isaiah Bowman School of
Geography is running a special
study of the effect of climatic
conditions on the human body for
the U. S. Quartermaster Corps.
Dr. D. H. K. Lee, acting head of
the School of Geography is directing the experiment. He is assisted
by Dr. R. B. Casady, a physiologist
on a one year leave of absence
from North Carolina State.

experiment. They will be subjected
to temperatures ranging from 95
degrees to 130 degrees, relative
humidity between 10 per cent and
72 per cent, and air movement
ranging from less than 1 mile per
hour to 10 miles ,per hour.
There will be 54 exposure periods, both in - the nude and
clothed, extending throughout the
winter. They will last two hours
each. The subjects will be paid
three dollars for each period and
will receive a bonus of one dollar
per period if they complete the
series.

A Concrete Suggestion On Spirit
With so many of the campus leaders involved in boosting
what they call "spirit", we would like to resort once more to an
old bag of junk which has 'accumulated in the News-Let teer office,
and come forth with a suggestion.
For years, there has been a very real division of people
on campus, which could well be exploited by the spiriters. While
they try to work on competition between classes, the true point
for competition has been completely neglected. We refer, of
course, to the division by schools. It has long been felt, by people
on various sides of the campus, that: all engineres are uncultured,
uncouth, and probably unclean; all humanities majors are unbalanced loafers; and all pre-meds are simply immature
nincompoops.

The Hopkins "Lilywhite Athletic Policy," more commonly
called the CEFCL Policy (Convenient Excuse For Consistent
Losing), has struck a new low
chord during the past two years.
First the wrestling team vacated
its mat-covered haunts and now
the chess team has joined the
march to oblivion.
Complete abandonment of inter-collegiate athletics is the only
step that has not been taken and,
rather than see it die on its feet
for lack of supervision, we wish
to extend a wholehearted plea to
the administration to deliver the
death blow now while some vestige of self respect remains.
To be explicit, we are arguing
the banishment of intercollegiate
athletics but not intercollegiate
competition. There is a difference. Competition can be had in
many ways besides on the athletic
field, even in a smoke-filled room.
Yes, even a smoke-filled room and
herein lies the gist of our suggestion.

panding fad of intercollegiate pipe
smoking.
For the uninformed, competitive
pipe smoking is conducted in the
following manner, with a few
minor variations among the various leagues. Contestants sit opposite each other in as small a
room as possible. The room must
be air-tight. Each man is given
3.3 grams of tobacco—the brand
to be decided by the coaches before the meet and two regular
wooden kitchen matches.
The
smoker must provide 'his own
briar. At a given signal each man
lights his pipe with one of the
matches and puffs away until his
coal finally dies. He is then allowed to re-ignite his pipefull with
the second match and remains in
the contest until no more smoke
issues from his puckered lips.
The object of the meet is, of
course, to outsmoke the other
team. Top points go to the man
who keeps his ember lit the longest and a graduated number of
points go to the rest of the men
in the order in which they finish.

"Much Ado About Nothing"
These definitions are the real beginning of competition. Class Not For Purists Of Bard
Day should really be School Day, with

representatives of the
three groups battling one another for the glory of their section
of the campus. Even the program could be changed. Replacing
the old push-ball battle could be a miniature war, with armies
meeting to test their various weapons. Slide rules versus dissecting
tools, both attacked by the arts force bearing fountain pens,
with classical literature as a heavy weapon, would be the order
of the day. Commanding officers in the battle would of course
be ROTC boys, out for real practice in tactical warfare.
The prize, instead of the traditional beer, would have to be
altered for the winner. The engineers would get beer, but
humaniities men would receive some "adequate red wine." Premeds would be issued small amounts of straight ethyl alcohol.
Trophies and plaques would be engraved in one of three ways;
Latin for the school of air and sunshine, pig latin and mathematical
symbols for the engineers, and a meaningless collection of the
best phrases of Freud, in the original German, for the medics.
This would be a competition worthy of the name.

Once again the fraternities have demonstrated that in almost
any group of incoming freshmen, regardless of how much stress
the admissions office has put on .scholasticism, they have a permanent place in Hopkins undergraduate life. Fortunately, due
largely to the activity of Dick Cohn and Bob Larimer, president
and vice-president of the IFB, the greeks also showed that it is
possible to conduct a rush season which is at least reasonably clean.
All in all, 13 violations came before the IFB. Last year, when
fraternity men admitted • that the rush season was one of the
(lirtiest within memory, no one was ever brought to trial. A4though
it is probable that this by no means covers every violation, it at
least shows that the fraternities, can keep their own house clean.
Sitting on the sidelines, watching this rushing season, it has
occurred to us that perhaps, still more improvements can be
made in the rushing rules. The greatest weakness in the system
as it stands is in the trial procedure. In any organization except
the Honor Commission, trial procedure is bound to be biased by the
personal and fraternal affiliation of the judges. This is particularly
true of the IFB, which of necessity conducts its trials when interfraternity feeling is at its height.
We don't know how this can be,avoided. Perhaps the easiest
way is to abolish the formal rushing rules entirely. Rushing could
be conducted under a blanket rule of gentlemanly conduct.

Official Records
Pipessmoking is not without its

history and records. Not knowing
its history we are, at this time,
unable to present it. However, the
records are intact-and in our possession. The international record
for smoking endurance is held by
a Dutch student at the Univerity
of Leyden, Holland, who puffed
for 59 minutes. The unofficial
American record is held by Walt
Bossert, a senior at Columbia
University, who kept his coal glowing for 43 minutes, 10 seconds.
One danger of this type of competition is exemplified by a recent
match between Columbia and the
University of Virginia. Forty-eight
men lit up, disappeared into a
mass of all-engulfing smoke, and
haven't been heard from since.
According to latest reports, rescue
operations have been hampered by
the smoke which still blankets
Charlottesville.
Yesterday we pulled our dusty
imported briar off the shelf, filled
it with four-week old Edgeworth,
and took a try at the sport. Unfortunately we "flamed out" at
34 minutes but we would have
done better if we hadn't slipped
on the 20-yard line. The try-forpoint failed.

Homewood, Baltimore, November 13, 1953

Jays Smash To First Victory
In 13-Year Series With Terps
In their most outstanding performance of the year, the Hopkins soccer team downed a cocky
University of Maryland squad 2-0
last Tuesday for their first victory
over the Terrapins since the series was initiated in 1938.
The Jays entered the game
heavy underdogs, due to Maryland's upset win over Navy coupled
with Hopkins' loss to Drexel. However, the Jays were not to be
denied.

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor
To Many Indians—Too Feu; Chiefs

In past Nests we have endeavored to show that at Hopkins
the purpose of the athletic program is to provide an educational
outlet in all fields of athletic activity in which our students show
interest. If The Hopkins falls down in any phase of its program it
is not fulfilling its purpose. It has been our contention that the
department has not been fulfilling this purpose. One example
of this is the definite lack of a sufficient number of competent
coaches to handle the numerous teams we put on the field.

After holding the Terps at bay
throughout most of the first period, Hopkins jumped into the lead
as Jim Hutchins blasted one of
his own rebounds into the nets
with only 3 minutes remaining
in the canto.

The most pronounced example of this lack of coaching is the
plight of the cross-country team which was made mention of last
week. Although we realize this to be the most obvious case of
blatant failure on the part of the administrators, there are other
similar situations which as yet have not reached this extreme.
This year the Hopkins has probably the best cross-country
team in its history', however, the student participants have attained
this height with the absolute minimum of help and support from
the department of athletics. The team has been under the direction
of their student captain, ever since the day school started. Mr.
Marshall Turner, Director of Athletics, was listed as the coach of
both the frosh and varsity harrier squads early in the season,
but he has spent little time with them. This is easily explainable
since Mr. Turner has a number of duties to perform' this fall as
frosh football coach, and athletic director along with the crosscountry team. We cannot and our administrators should not
have thought that one man could handle all the positions capably,
currently held by Mr.-Turner.
Harriers Hit War Path

To whom can this unsatiSfactory set-up be traced? It can be
traced only as far as the athletic office, in that they must have
known what the situation would have been this fall. Sure they
bad no easy job in finding men to fill all of the vacancies last
summer, but it seems as though they forgot about cross-country.
Considering that for the past two years an unhealthy setup has
existed in this sport, just how could they forget about them?
The shaky past can be attributed to the same cause as the present
one in that Carl Rees, like Marshall Turner, was called upon to
handle both hill-and-dale teams plus act as assistant football
coach. Therefore, the team has not had a full time coach since the
1950 season when Clyde Heuther literally saved the sport by
contributing an exceptionally good job with a sixteen man frosh
squad.
At times the department even sinks to the depth of sending
the varsity squad to away meets without a coach (considered drastic
last year, but a usual happening this season), something which is
not only bad for the team, but also weak public relations. To the
• schools we visit, Hopkins certainly doesn't look like it maintains
a well organized sports program when a team shows up without
any faculty direction. The department has continually failed to
give the sport a fair-break and a few of the brave men who have
stuck it out thus far are purrently saying that "the athletic
department must want to cut us out completely like they did the
wrestlers." Well in the opinion of The Nester, if they aren't
admittedly attempting to abolish the sport they are certainly
going the wrong way in attempting to keep it here.
, No Wampum

Even though the student captain is the only "coach" the
squad has had lately, lie boasts only running experience but
naturally lacks any coaching experience. The college cannot
expect a student to hold the sport together forever, since The
'Nester can tell you straight forwardly that any student who
tries to coach, captain, and run cross-cpuntry should have his
bead examined.
As mentioned before, soccer and track tare in a similar
lack of coaches predicanient. Wliy is it the department realizes
the need for separate frosh and varsity mentors in football,
basketball, baseball, and lacrosse but not in soccer or track?
Our administrators claim that our program is for educational
benefits primarily, but they don't furnish teachers enough to
educate us. In our minds the problem all boils down to one bitter
conclusion, that being that there is a definite need of a larger
budget so as to enable the department to enlarge. LET'S

Freshman Football Squad To Encounter
Green Terrors In Season's Last Game
This afternoon at 2:30, the
freshman football team meets
Western Maryland's junior varsity eleven at Homewood Field in
its last game of the season.
After travelling all the way to
Swarthmore, the frosh were unable to play because of the heavy
snow last Friday.
Coach Marshall Turner feels
that his charges had improved considerably up until the unplayed
Swarthmore test, but the loss of
practice due to the snow might
have slowed the team's progress.
Turner plans to start the same
line-up that was scheduled to play
last week.

left end; Tom Ustach, left tackle;

Chuck Soliz at fullback; and either
Houston Hemphill or Jimmy Valis
at tailback.
Carr Injured

been unable to do much running
and is therefore playing blocking
back; but he, along with Gallagher, has been outstanding on
defense. According to Turner,
Soliz has been playing the most
consistent ball on offense.

AND DEVELOPMENT
Call for Knowledge, Ingenuity, Teamwork
Making new products in large amounts, devising new processes, and improving old ones—such problems are the job of
Design and Development. An example was the development
of a large-scale process for making "Orion" acrylic fiber
starting from small laboratory samples of polyacrylonitrile.
Quantity production of polymer was only a beginning. A
whole set of new and unusual problems arose in spinning the
fiber, because polyacrylonitrile decomposes before it melts,
and it dissolves only in high-boiling solvents.
A team of Du Pont technical men—chemical and mechanical engineers,instrumentation specialists, metallurgists, and
materials handling experts undertook to find a solution.
Here are a few of the problems they met:
1. Solve problems in heat transfer and fluid flow
arising from the fact that the spinning solution
must be blanketed with inert gas to prevent fire
hazards.
2. Design a system for controlling the temperature of the viscous spinning solution within ±0.5°F.
at hundreds of points in the plant.
3. Design new mechanisms for winding yarn at
high speed without any deviation in yarn tension.
4. Design air conditioning and ventilating systems to remove fumes from specific spots, but
still allow easy access to all areas.

A Concrete Suggestion On Spirit
With so many of the campus leaders involved in boosting
what they call "spirit", we would like to resort once more to an
old bag of junk which has 'accumulated in the News-Let teer office,
and come forth with a suggestion.
For years, there has been a very real division of people
on campus, which could well be exploited by the spiriters. While
they try to work on competition between classes, the true point
for competition has been completely neglected. We refer, of
course, to the division by schools. It has long been felt, by people
on various sides of the campus, that: all engineres are uncultured,
uncouth, and probably unclean; all humanities majors are unbalanced loafers; and all pre-meds are simply immature
nincompoops.

The Hopkins "Lilywhite Athletic Policy," more commonly
called the CEFCL Policy (Convenient Excuse For Consistent
Losing), has struck a new low
chord during the past two years.
First the wrestling team vacated
its mat-covered haunts and now
the chess team has joined the
march to oblivion.
Complete abandonment of inter-collegiate athletics is the only
step that has not been taken and,
rather than see it die on its feet
for lack of supervision, we wish
to extend a wholehearted plea to
the administration to deliver the
death blow now while some vestige of self respect remains.
To be explicit, we are arguing
the banishment of intercollegiate
athletics but not intercollegiate
competition. There is a difference. Competition can be had in
many ways besides on the athletic
field, even in a smoke-filled room.
Yes, even a smoke-filled room and
herein lies the gist of our suggestion.

panding fad of intercollegiate pipe
smoking.
For the uninformed, competitive
pipe smoking is conducted in the
following manner, with a few
minor variations among the various leagues. Contestants sit opposite each other in as small a
room as possible. The room must
be air-tight. Each man is given
3.3 grams of tobacco—the brand
to be decided by the coaches before the meet and two regular
wooden kitchen matches.
The
smoker must provide 'his own
briar. At a given signal each man
lights his pipe with one of the
matches and puffs away until his
coal finally dies. He is then allowed to re-ignite his pipefull with
the second match and remains in
the contest until no more smoke
issues from his puckered lips.
The object of the meet is, of
course, to outsmoke the other
team. Top points go to the man
who keeps his ember lit the longest and a graduated number of
points go to the rest of the men
in the order in which they finish.

"Much Ado About Nothing"
These definitions are the real beginning of competition. Class Not For Purists Of Bard
Day should really be School Day, with

representatives of the
three groups battling one another for the glory of their section
of the campus. Even the program could be changed. Replacing
the old push-ball battle could be a miniature war, with armies
meeting to test their various weapons. Slide rules versus dissecting
tools, both attacked by the arts force bearing fountain pens,
with classical literature as a heavy weapon, would be the order
of the day. Commanding officers in the battle would of course
be ROTC boys, out for real practice in tactical warfare.
The prize, instead of the traditional beer, would have to be
altered for the winner. The engineers would get beer, but
humaniities men would receive some "adequate red wine." Premeds would be issued small amounts of straight ethyl alcohol.
Trophies and plaques would be engraved in one of three ways;
Latin for the school of air and sunshine, pig latin and mathematical
symbols for the engineers, and a meaningless collection of the
best phrases of Freud, in the original German, for the medics.
This would be a competition worthy of the name.

Once again the fraternities have demonstrated that in almost
any group of incoming freshmen, regardless of how much stress
the admissions office has put on .scholasticism, they have a permanent place in Hopkins undergraduate life. Fortunately, due
largely to the activity of Dick Cohn and Bob Larimer, president
and vice-president of the IFB, the greeks also showed that it is
possible to conduct a rush season which is at least reasonably clean.
All in all, 13 violations came before the IFB. Last year, when
fraternity men admitted • that the rush season was one of the
(lirtiest within memory, no one was ever brought to trial. A4though
it is probable that this by no means covers every violation, it at
least shows that the fraternities, can keep their own house clean.
Sitting on the sidelines, watching this rushing season, it has
occurred to us that perhaps, still more improvements can be
made in the rushing rules. The greatest weakness in the system
as it stands is in the trial procedure. In any organization except
the Honor Commission, trial procedure is bound to be biased by the
personal and fraternal affiliation of the judges. This is particularly
true of the IFB, which of necessity conducts its trials when interfraternity feeling is at its height.
We don't know how this can be,avoided. Perhaps the easiest
way is to abolish the formal rushing rules entirely. Rushing could
be conducted under a blanket rule of gentlemanly conduct.

Pipessmoking is not without its

history and records. Not knowing
its history we are, at this time,
unable to present it. However, the
records are intact-and in our possession. The international record
for smoking endurance is held by
a Dutch student at the Univerity
of Leyden, Holland, who puffed
for 59 minutes. The unofficial
American record is held by Walt
Bossert, a senior at Columbia
University, who kept his coal glowing for 43 minutes, 10 seconds.
One danger of this type of competition is exemplified by a recent
match between Columbia and the
University of Virginia. Forty-eight
men lit up, disappeared into a
mass of all-engulfing smoke, and
haven't been heard from since.
According to latest reports, rescue
operations have been hampered by
the smoke which still blankets
Charlottesville.

Homewood, Baltimore, November 13, 1953

Jays Smash To First Victory
In 13-Year Series With Terps
In their most outstanding performance of the year, the Hopkins soccer team downed a cocky
University of Maryland squad 2-0
last Tuesday for their first victory
over the Terrapins since the series was initiated in 1938.
The Jays entered the game
heavy underdogs, due to Maryland's upset win over Navy coupled
with Hopkins' loss to Drexel. However, the Jays were not to be
denied.

By TOM STONE, Sports Editor
To Many Indians—Too Feu; Chiefs

In past Nests we have endeavored to show that at Hopkins
the purpose of the athletic program is to provide an educational
outlet in all fields of athletic activity in which our students show
interest. If The Hopkins falls down in any phase of its program it
is not fulfilling its purpose. It has been our contention that the
department has not been fulfilling this purpose. One example
of this is the definite lack of a sufficient number of competent
coaches to handle the numerous teams we put on the field.

After holding the Terps at bay
throughout most of the first period, Hopkins jumped into the lead
as Jim Hutchins blasted one of
his own rebounds into the nets
with only 3 minutes remaining
in the canto.

The most pronounced example of this lack of coaching is the
plight of the cross-country team which was made mention of last
week. Although we realize this to be the most obvious case of
blatant failure on the part of the administrators, there are other
similar situations which as yet have not reached this extreme.
This year the Hopkins has probably the best cross-country
team in its history', however, the student participants have attained
this height with the absolute minimum of help and support from
the department of athletics. The team has been under the direction
of their student captain, ever since the day school started. Mr.
Marshall Turner, Director of Athletics, was listed as the coach of
both the frosh and varsity harrier squads early in the season,
but he has spent little time with them. This is easily explainable
since Mr. Turner has a number of duties to perform' this fall as
frosh football coach, and athletic director along with the crosscountry team. We cannot and our administrators should not
have thought that one man could handle all the positions capably,
currently held by Mr.-Turner.
Harriers Hit War Path

To whom can this unsatiSfactory set-up be traced? It can be
traced only as far as the athletic office, in that they must have
known what the situation would have been this fall. Sure they
bad no easy job in finding men to fill all of the vacancies last
summer, but it seems as though they forgot about cross-country.
Considering that for the past two years an unhealthy setup has
existed in this sport, just how could they forget about them?
The shaky past can be attributed to the same cause as the present
one in that Carl Rees, like Marshall Turner, was called upon to
handle both hill-and-dale teams plus act as assistant football
coach. Therefore, the team has not had a full time coach since the
1950 season when Clyde Heuther literally saved the sport by
contributing an exceptionally good job with a sixteen man frosh
squad.
At times the department even sinks to the depth of sending
the varsity squad to away meets without a coach (considered drastic
last year, but a usual happening this season), something which is
not only bad for the team, but also weak public relations. To the
• schools we visit, Hopkins certainly doesn't look like it maintains
a well organized sports program when a team shows up without
any faculty direction. The department has continually failed to
give the sport a fair-break and a few of the brave men who have
stuck it out thus far are purrently saying that "the athletic
department must want to cut us out completely like they did the
wrestlers." Well in the opinion of The Nester, if they aren't
admittedly attempting to abolish the sport they are certainly
going the wrong way in attempting to keep it here.
, No Wampum

Even though the student captain is the only "coach" the
squad has had lately, lie boasts only running experience but
naturally lacks any coaching experience. The college cannot
expect a student to hold the sport together forever, since The
'Nester can tell you straight forwardly that any student who
tries to coach, captain, and run cross-cpuntry should have his
bead examined.
As mentioned before, soccer and track tare in a similar
lack of coaches predicanient. Wliy is it the department realizes
the need for separate frosh and varsity mentors in football,
basketball, baseball, and lacrosse but not in soccer or track?
Our administrators claim that our program is for educational
benefits primarily, but they don't furnish teachers enough to
educate us. In our minds the problem all boils down to one bitter
conclusion, that being that there is a definite need of a larger
budget so as to enable the department to enlarge. LET'S
